flab

flab.BootManager module

The BootManager module contains classes that are used to configure flab environments, in which devices, variables and tasks may be synchronized between different processes and threads. A few configurations are possible, depending on the desired application, which are specified in the init method.

class flab.BootManager.BootManager(server=False, client=False, print_status=True)

Bases: object

BootManager contains methods for configuring the main process by creating managers for synchronizing devices, tasks, variables, etc. across processes and threads, as well as remote/local server/client communication. Version 2.0.2

create_flab_proxy(ui_queue=None, flab_queue=None, print_status=True)

creates a proxy Flab object to enable pickling i.e. synchronization of a Flab object across threads and processes

Parameters

  • ui_queue (Queue) – The queue for sending commands to the UI process. None by default

  • flab_queue (Queue) – The queue for sending commands to the Flab process. None by default

  • flab_queue – The queue for sending commands to the Flab process. None by default

  • print_status (boolean) – If outputs should be printed. True by default.

Returns

flab_proxy object

create_queue()

Returns

Queue

Creates a remote queue manager and machine/client queue for communication

Parameters

  • address – IP address of the communicating server

  • authkey (str) – authentication key

  • server (boolean) – indicates if the main process is a server

Type

address: boolean

Returns

None

start_process(flab, task_name, *args, blocking=False)

Starts a task as a process

Parameters

  • flab (Flab) – the flab object

  • task_name (str) – the task name

  • args – arguments to be passed to the given task

  • blocking (boolean) – if the task should block. False by default

Returns

None

start_processes(flab, task_names, *args, blocking=False)

Starts multiple tasks as processes simultaneously

Parameters

  • flab (Flab) – the flab object

  • task_names ([str]) – the task name

  • args (tuple) – a multidimensional tuple, where each element consists of the process arguments for each task

  • blocking (boolean) – if the task should block. False by default

Returns

None

version = '2.0.2'
class flab.BootManager.FlabManager(address=None, authkey=None, serializer='pickle', ctx=None)

Bases: SyncManager

a manager class for sharing flab objects across local processes. Inherits the multiprocessing class SyncManager

class flab.BootManager.RemoteManager(address=None, authkey=None, serializer='pickle', ctx=None)

Bases: SyncManager

A manager class for sharing flab objects across networks. Inherits the multiprocessing class SyncManager

flab.DeviceManager module

The DeviceManager module contains classes and methods for creating and manipulating devices

class flab.DeviceManager.DeviceManager

Bases: object

A class for dynamically creating and sharing device objects. Devices do not necessarily have publicly accessible attributes, and a “get_attr” method may be needed to access these attributes. Version 2.0.2

get_devices()

returns devices in a flab object

Returns

a list of device names

register_devices(device_names)

registers a list of devices within a project with the FlabDeviceManager. This is required before the devices are loaded into a flab object.

reload_device(device_name)

Reloads a single device into flab. This only reloads the main device class, not the associated drivers and protocols. This is now deprecated after v1.0.0

class flab.DeviceManager.FlabDeviceManager(address=None, authkey=None, serializer='pickle', ctx=None)

Bases: SyncManager

A manager class for sharing devices in a flab object and across threads and processes. Extends the multiprocessing class SyncManager

flab.Flab module

The Flab module contains the Flab and FlabNamespace classes, which are used for sharing of attributes, methods, variables and other objects

class flab.Flab.Flab(ui_queue=None, flab_queue=None, print_status=True)

Bases: DeviceManager, TaskManager, UiManager

Flab inherits DeviceManager, TaskManager, UiManager and BotManager and contains dictionaries for devices, tasks, vars, uis and bots. Version 2.0.2

__init__(ui_queue=None, flab_queue=None, print_status=True)

Constructs the Flab object, containing empty dictionaries

Flab objects can be constructed with two queues for exchanging information between processes.

Parameters

  • ui_queue (multiprocessing.Queue(,queue.Queue)) – queue object that passes information to UI processes, defaults to None

  • flab_queue (multiprocessing.Queue(,queue.Queue)) – queue object that passes information to flab processes, defaults to None

  • print_status – a boolean indicating if output should be sent to the command prompt, defaults to True

Returns

None

add_var(value, variable_name) → None

adds a variable with a given value to the variable dictionary

Parameters

  • value (numbers, strings, lists, objects, etc.) – value of the variable

  • variable_name (str) – the name of the variable

Returns

None

Do not use devices, tasks, bots or uis in the variable dictionary. Avoid nested dictionaries and complex objects.

close_flab() → None

Ends all running processes and tasks within a Flab object

Returns

None

close_queues() → None

Closes any open queues

Returns

None

create_project_directory(parent_path, project_name) → None

Creates a project directory with a given name at a given parent path

For example, create_project_directory(‘C:/Projects’,’MyFirstProject’) yields a directory with the following structure.

C:/Projects/

└ MyFirstProject/

├ Boot/

├ Tasks/

├ Devices/

│ ├ Drivers/

│ └ Protocols/

├ UIs/

│ ├ Actions/

│ ├ Designs/

│ └ Windows/

└ Bots/

└ Algorithms/

Parameters

  • parent_path (str) – full path of the parent directory (typically Projects)

  • project_name (str) – Name of the project

Returns

None

display(object) → None

Displays an object by printing to the command prompt and/or passing to ui_queue

Parameters

object – an object

Returns

None

Displays a message. For example, message(‘HelloWorld’) leads to the display of “message: Hello World”

version = '2.0.2'
class flab.Flab.FlabNamespace

Bases: object

A namespace for a Flab object which contains the information on the contained objects (e.g. Devices, Tasks, variables)

__init__() → None

The constructor defines the namespace attributes with the following code:

self.devices = []
self.tasks = []
self.bots = []
self.vars = []
self.modules = []
self.uis = []
self.print_status = []
self.is_running = []
self.running_tasks = []
self.device_attributes = {}
self.device_methods = {}
self.device_method_args = {}
self.device_method_arg_descriptions = {}

flab.TaskManager module

The TaskManager module includes classes and methods for creating and running synchronous/simultaneous routines

class flab.TaskManager.TaskManager

Bases: object

The TaskManager class contains methods for loading, running and terminating tasks implementing python’s threading library, asyncio, and multiprocessing Version 2.0.2

start_asyncio_task(task_name, *args, **kwargs)

Start an asyncio task by first creating an asyncio task to “main” from the run method, putting this into a separate thread.

Parameters

  • task_name (str) – name of the task

  • args – task arguments

  • kwargs – task keyword arguments

Returns

None

start_asyncio_tasks(task_names, *args, **kwargs)

start multiple asyncio tasks within the same thread by creating one “main” method which is comprised of multiple asyncio tasks created from task run methods

Parameters

  • task_names (list of strings) – names of the tasks

  • args – task arguments

  • kwargs – task keyword arguments

Returns

None

start_process(task_name, *args, blocking=False)

Start a process with the run method, with input arguments args and kwargs

Parameters

  • task_name (str) – name of the task

  • args – args for the task

  • blocking (boolean) – if the task is blocking (False by default)

Returns

None

start_processes(task_names, *args, blocking=False)

Start multiple processes at once.

Parameters

  • task_names ([str]) – name of the task

  • args – args is a multidimensional tuple, where each element consists of the process arguments

  • blocking (boolean) – if the task is blocking (False by default)

Returns

None

start_task(task_name, *args, **kwargs)

start a task using the “run” method. By default this runs each task as a thread, but if the task type is specified otherwise, it will start the task as an asyncio thread or a process

Parameters

  • task_name (str) – name of the task

  • args – arguments for the task

  • kwargs – keyword arguments for the task

Returns

None

start_thread(task_name, *args, **kwargs)

Start a thread with the run method, with input arguments args and kwargs

Parameters

  • task_name (str) – name of the task

  • args – task arguments

  • kwargs – task keyword arguments

Returns

None

stop_all_tasks()

this method stops all running tasks

Returns

None

stop_asyncio_task(task_name, *args, **kwargs)

Stop an asyncio task similarly to starting, but creating the main asyncio task from the stop method

Parameters

  • task_name (str) – name of the task

  • args – task arguments

  • kwargs – task keyword arguments

Returns

None

stop_asyncio_tasks(task_names, *args, **kwargs)

stop multiple asyncio tasks similarly to starting multiple asyncio tasks, but using the stop methods. Note: this will not stop multiple asyncio tasks if the asyncio tasks have not been run all together using “start_asyncio_tasks”

Parameters

  • task_names ([str]) – name of the tasks

  • args – task arguments

  • kwargs – task keyword arguments

Returns

None

stop_process(task_name, *args, blocking=True)

stop a process by terminating the running task, then calling the stop method of the process as another process.

Parameters

  • task_name (str) – the task name

  • args – args is a multidimensional tuple, where each element consists of the process arguments

  • blocking (boolean) – if the task is blocking (True by default)

Returns

None

stop_task(task_name, *args, **kwargs)

Stop a task using the task’s “stop” method. By default this runs each task as a thread, but if the task type is specified otherwise, it will start the task as an asyncio thread or a process.

Parameters

  • task_name (str) – name of the task

  • args – arguments for the task

  • kwargs – keyword arguments for the task

Returns

None

stop_thread(task_name, *args, **kwargs)

Stop a thread with the stop method, with input arguments args and kwargs.

Parameters

  • task_name (str) – name of the task

  • args – task arguments

  • kwargs – task keyword arguments

Returns

None

flab.UiManager module

The UIManager module contains class and methods for creating, loading and converting UIs

class flab.UiManager.UiManager

Bases: object

A class containing methods for converting and loading UIs. Note: PyQT interfaces generally need to bed be started within a main method or separate process

convert_ui(ui_file_name)

Converts a UI from a ui file to python file with the same name within the “Designs” folder using the PyQt library. This method is now deprecated to reduce dependencies on PyQt.

Parameters

ui_file_name (str) – name of the .ui file in the Designs folder

Returns

None

ui object or None
